8.author: AvadaCaCanteven
8.body:
Weird, you ask me if English is my first language yet Meriam Webster seems to think my stance holds merit.

MW dictionary:

1:conscious exertion of power : hard work
2: a serious attempt : TRY
3: something produced by exertion or trying
4: effective force as distinguished from the possible resistance called into action by such a force
5: the total work done to achieve a particular end

Based on #2 & #5, even if I attempted a boss and did it flawlessly there was still effort made as it was a serious attempt. I have a feeling you won't agree tho.

8.author: CantGraspTheConcept
8.body:
If you are playing "seriously" then it was an attempt that requires effort. You don't "seriously attempt" to drink a cup of water because it requires no effort. If I'm goofing around with a 10 pound weight because it weighs nothing to me then that requires no effort. If I'm holding 40 pounds, it's not that heavy but it still requires I am least hold it correctly. 

There's a reason the phrase "maximum effort" was coined > because it means you put actual focus and put forth your biggest *effort*.

8.author: AvadaCaCanteven
8.body: Lol I see I was right on my previous reply. I feel like my points been made. Have a good one!

8.author: CantGraspTheConcept
8.body:
You are very smug for someone who is definitively wrong.

Effort means:

1. **conscious exertion** of power : hard work  
*a job requiring time and effort* 

2. a **serious** attempt : TRY  
*making an effort to reduce costs* 

3. something produced by exertion or **trying**  
*the novel was her most ambitious effort* 

4. effective force as distinguished from the possible resistance called into action by such a force 

5. the total work done to achieve a particular end  
*the war effort*

Number 2 straight up requires a *serious attempt.* It's like words don't matter to you. If I am doing something that does not require me to try, then it does not require effort. My 6 year old understands that man I am trying really hard to say it as simply as possible.

Number 5 is referring to the achievement of something due to your long term effort. *I.E. You won a competition because of all the effort you put in practicing in addition to the effort you put in during the competition.*  Effortlessly is a word too - It means showing or requiring little or no effort.

My final word: By putting in tremendous amounts of effort, you can do some things in the same category without effort. I can give you literal examples all day, but hopefully you are actually not responding anymore.

8.author: CantGraspTheConcept
8.body: Just a reminder that your entire argument can be summed up by saying you don't think training until something becomes effortless is a thing.

8.author: AvadaCaCanteven
8.body:
And just a reminder your entire argument can be summed up to "effort disappears when trying to achieve something when you hit an ever changing baseline depending on the situation". Meaning your definition is nebulous at best while mine can fit a majority of situations easily and with clarity.

Also mine still fits the definition.

8.author: CantGraspTheConcept
8.body:
Yours doesn't fit the definition and you are taking this idea that "effort disappearing" is a negative thing when really it's just how training works. You train which makes it so things that used to require effort are now effortless. Your argument means the term effortless just doesn't exist anymore. And again, the definition requires actually trying so your argument does not meet the definition because at some point with enough training you can do things without trying - that doesn't mean the effort you put into the training magically disappears, it just means that it shows how much effort went into getting to where you are today. But effort directly relates to how hard you are trying at a specific task. You can talk about effort in the past tense as well which is kind of what you are referring to because your past effort doesn't go away but that doesn't mean the current task you are focused on requires effort. 

I guess thinking about it like that, being able to now effortlessly do a task that was once difficult, you have displayed the effort that it took to get to that level of performance even though said performance was done without effort.

8.author: AvadaCaCanteven
8.body:
>I guess thinking about it like that, being able to now effortlessly do a task that was once difficult, you have displayed the effort that it took to get to that level of performance even though said performance was done without effort.

Well put and imo is the best way to view effort. To me the amount of things that are truly effortless is so small, it's almost a useless word. People subjectively think things are effortless but they rarely are and it feels like you're minimizing the effort the person put into making it seem effortless.
